metadata.title: US State – Chinese Province Sister Relationships
metadata.description: Confirmed sister state/province pairings between US states and Chinese provinces/municipalities. Research compiled Feb 2026 from Chinese consulate records, state government sites, and CPAFFC reports.
metadata.note_on_duplicates: This is NOT a 1:1 mapping. Some US states have multiple Chinese partners and vice versa. The 23 entries below represent 23 distinct bilateral agreements across 17 unique Chinese provinces/municipalities and 20 unique US states.
sources: CPAFFC (Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries)
News archives (Xinhua, China Daily, local US media)

pairings.rationale: First US-China sister state pairing. Both industrial heartlands and transportation hubs with significant agriculture. Established same year as US-China diplomatic normalization.
Early pairing in the wave of post-normalization agreements.
Both densely populated coastal provinces with strong manufacturing and trade economies.
Both major wheat/grain producers on flat fertile plains. Agricultural similarity was the primary driver.
Note: Shaanxi (陕西, capital Xi'an) is distinct from Shanxi (山西). The double-A spelling distinguishes them in romanization.
Both major industrial centers with auto/manufacturing focus.
Both cold-climate agricultural powerhouses with dairy industry focus.
Historical ties: 18th-century Canton trade connections. Most Chinese-Americans in MA trace roots to Guangdong.
Both agricultural giants. Xi Jinping visited Iowa from Hebei in 1985 on agricultural tour, creating deep personal connection. He returned in 2012 as Vice President.
Both forested, mountainous, coastal regions with similar climates. Crater Lake and Wuyishan are sister parks.
Heavy industry bases. Illinois opened first US state trade office in China (Shenyang, Liaoning's capital).
Both inland, arid regions with energy and agricultural sectors.
Both mountainous with natural beauty, agriculture, and coal/mining industries. Note: Shanxi (山西, 'west of mountains') is distinct from Shaanxi (陕西).
Both tropical islands with tourism-driven economies. Hainan is often called 'China's Hawaii'.
Both coastal with strong educational institutions and mixed economies.
Zhejiang's second US state partner (also paired with New Jersey since 1981).
Both economic powerhouses. Jiangsu has the largest provincial GDP in China.
Both northern, cold-climate regions with forestry and agriculture.
Fujian's second US state partner (also paired with Oregon since 1984).
Two largest sub-national economies in their respective countries. Both tech/innovation hubs.
Oregon's second Chinese partner (also paired with Fujian since 1984). Tianjin is a direct-administered municipality.
Michigan's second Chinese partner (also paired with Sichuan since 1982). Guangdong's third US partner.
Friendship agreement only, not a full sister state relationship. Sichuan's second US partner.
